title: On 1 March 2021, how many states will have a number of daily new COVID-19 cases per 100k residents of 75.0 or higher?
preds:
On 01 Feb 2021, Texas had 31,811new confirmed cases out of 105,238 new tests.
On 19 Feb 2021, Texas had a number of new reported tests of 401,870, very likely postponed report from the previous winter storm days. So far, the highest number 0f new confirmed cases after 13 February 2021 was 11,809 cases/23 Feb 2021.
It seems the bulk of test results of the second half of February 2021 has not yet been fed into reports. I'm thrilled whether there will be a one-off effect of delayed reports, specifically from Houston and Dallas metro area, that could send the TX figures over the threshold of roughly 22,000 new cases on 01 March 2021.
https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas The next possible highest state, SC, seems to be out of the danger zone at 42.6 as of time of writing.
Currently the highest in the US is CT with 33.4/100,000 Even NYC is only at 45.8

https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#cases_casesper100klast7days New Jersey and South Caroline have the highest cases /100k, each coming in at 32.5
Seems unlikely that either will surpass 75 by the end of the week (or that another state will surpass that).
The highest rate is South Carolina, with 46.3.  I see very little chance any state gets to 75 or higher by 1 March at current trends.
The highest state currently is South Carolina with 46.8 new cases per 100K individuals.  This rate would need to increase by 2/3 in order to qualify for the 75 or greater than rate.
No state has a rate above 55%, and all trends point downward.
All states much lower, and trending down
Not expecting to see cases rise this month, only fall.

The highest state currently is South Carolina with 55.9 new cases per 100K people.  With cases declining across the country, the likelihood of having 75 cases or higher by March 1st is an incredibly remote chance.
Chance of a surge with a new variant
Keeping 98% for now. South Carolina is the only state currently threatening the 75 value by maintaining a rate over 60 for the last 10 days.
Actually becoming pretty confident. All of the states with increasing test positivity currently have very low case rates so are not threatening the 75 barrier

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC has declined to 0.837.  AK has the highest infection rate, 0.97, but only 25.4 new infections per 100k.  SC has the highest new case rate, 62.2 per 100k population, and its infection rate is 0.89.  All the numbers are heading in the right direction.  I'll bet heavily on "Zero."
Always possible for a spike to drive it back up around the timeframe, but the longer we go with the numbers going down the harder it will be to hit 75 even with a spike.

Massively increasing my chance of zero being the result. I initially thought 80% based on the updated data from today but I am usually too conservative. My final thought process was trying to work out which states I think are likely to breach the 75.0 by the end of the month and there were none. I can become more confident with time. Positivity rates are also dropping in almost all states of concern. South Carolina and Texas are biggest concerns.

TX and NC appear to have the highest probability of moving up to 75 cases per 100k.  They aren't too far below the 75 threshold, and have the highest infection rates, 0.99 and 0.97 respectively.  I'll watch the data closely, but for the time being will keep an overweight on "Zero."  The risk/reward ratio for going all in is too high at this point, IMHO.

Texas has the highest new case rate at 66 per 100k, and also has the highest infection rate of all the states, 1.00.  North Carolina's numbers are 61 and 0.97.  Other states are either way below 75 per 100k new cases, or their infection rate is well below 1.00, or both.  There is still time for the numbers to turn around, but I'll bet they won't.

Signs of decreasing rates in 47 states, all from below the threshold.
Increasing notably from already higher rates (over 50) in only 2 states.

The trend of the virus is encouraging.  Currently zero states have more than 75 new daily cases per 100k.  Based on seasonality and vaccines, I would expect the number of new cases to continue to decrease.
No states currently have a number of daily new COVID-19 cases per 100k residents of 75.0 or higher and COVID-19 cases are decreasing rapidly.
It is always dangerous to go early on a high probability for zero instances of something, so hoping (on behalf of the US) that that probability can steadily climb through february.

Today 0
Decrease
The re-emergence of the epidemic due to new variants can be compensated for by vaccines, weather, and restrictive measures.

Current rates are going down and currently seem to be around 50 cases per 100k.
If this trend continues, and the vaccination curve is kept (no additional severe delays), it should keep the number of cases down. 
Risks - new strains hitting the US, public holidays (President's Day) celebrations add a little risk

1, Arizona 75.4, 0
This is following the flu season curve. We are currently at one and within a day or two we will be at zero. There is talk of a aggressive european strain hitting us in the spring, but I think March 1 is too early for that, and we will have cross immunity. When people have been exposed or immunized we have yet to see how cross immune they are to other strains, but I am optimistic. T cell immunity plays a larger role with this disease than any other we've encountered, and t cells work well with cross immunity.

Today 1
Decrease
The re-emergence of the epidemic due to new variants can be compensated for by vaccines, weather, and restrictive measures.

Today: 2
Rapid decrease. 
The re-emergence of the epidemic due to new variants can be compensated for by vaccines, weather, and restrictive measures.

trending down..
British/South African/Brazil variants could boost numbers, but increasing vaccination numbers will counter...

2 AZ SC, 0
Every state now has an infection rate of less than 1.0.

Arizona would have to drop about 20% to 5.5k cases per day to hit the target (currently at about 7k cases per day) in the next month. That seems very doable. But I'm keeping an almost equal likelihood of 1 to 3, as all it would take is cases to persist or flare up in one state to negate the 0 bucket. But I think there will have been pretty significant drop in cases by a month from now so I'm heavily favoring the two lower buckets.
Most states are moving down, and away from the 75 threshold.  The chance of a "zero" outcome is increasing.

I think it's a bit binary between things getting better (masks, better social distancing etc) and worse (new variants, winter etc). Very hard to call given wild swings seen in the US & in other geographies, plus varying rules by state
Currently 2. B117 has yet to have a significant impact.

AZ and SC are currently the only states meeting the criteria.  According to covidactnow.org the reinfection rate for AZ is 0.93.  If this holds then AZ will fall below the 75 per 100k level by March 1.  SC has a reinfection rate of 1.03, and as of yesterday has 92.4 per 100k new infections.  I estimate (guess) a 50/50 chance for SC to be above 75 on March 1. NY, TX and KY are all a bit below the 75 level. But they have reinfection rates close to 1, with TX is slightly above 1.00.  A fairly small change could put TX, KY or NY above the 75 threshold. VA has the highest reinfection rate, 1.08, and is very close to the 75 level.  If the reinfection rate is correct, and if it continues, then VA will meet the criteria.  NH is also below 75, but has a reinfection rate of 1.02.   If Rt changes rapidly, or if it turns out to actually be higher than current estimates, then other states could also reach the 75 threshold.  According the projections at https://covid19-projections.com/path-to-herd-immunity/, new infections on Feb 22 (one week before the end of the question) will be down by about a third from the levels of Jan 22. The ongoing vaccination campaign should bias the numbers downward, but the more transmissive mutation could bias the numbers upward.  The CDC estimates that the B.1.1.7 will become the dominant virus sometime in March.  Since this question ends on March 1, I will underweight the possibility that the mutation will have a major effect before March 1. "The modeled trajectory of this variant in the U.S. exhibits rapid growth in early 2021, becoming the predominant variant in March."  See https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7003e2.htm. With 37 days remaining there is still considerable uncertainty.  I'll reduce my overweighting on the "Zero" outcome, but remain below the crowd for the higher ranges with the remainder of my chips.

2, 7
This is clearly following the normal flu season curve.
Down to 3 states. It's been a very quick drop. Can't go too low because 75 is a very achievable figure.
Slightly less chance of "Zero" outcome; moved two beans to "Between 1 and 3."

Down to 6 as of right now. Going back to what I was at before, though I added 5 to 10 or more on the chance that another wave has struck by then. I consider that possibility somewhat unlikely though due to increasing vaccine prevalence along with whatever herd immunity this last wave has caused.

As of today, the highest number is 101.1 in Arizona. A 25% reduction in new cases will put almost all states below the 75 threshold. Is this possible by March 1st? I think so, looking at the downward trend and Rt

Only 13 states have Rt>1.00.  The average Rt for the 50 states + DC fell again today, to 0.957.  Total new US infections have fallen commensurately.  IMHO, the states most likely to have 75 or higher infections per million on March 1 are AZ, KY, MS, OK, VA, and WY. This assumes that the Rt numbers are reliable indicators of the trend.  That has not always been the case, as forecasters, myself included, learned in another question.  And even if correct, Rt can increase quickly if people become complacent.  Still, with a positive trend in place and vaccine numbers increasing, I'll continue to bet on lower infection rates.  But I'll watch for news of virus mutations, which could blow up my whole thesis. "Scott Gottlieb, a former Food and Drug Administration commissioner, warned that the advent of more transmissible variants could reverse progress.
As current epidemic surge peaks, we may see 3-4 weeks of declines in new cases but then [the] new variant will take over,” Gottlieb tweeted Sunday, referring to the British variant. 'It’ll double in prevalence about every week. It’ll change the game and could mean we have persistent high infection through spring until we vaccinate enough people.'" See https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/01/18/california-coronavirus-variant/
Looks like most of the states above 75.0 have peaked on January 11th and now trending downwards. If this trend continues, by March 1st, almost all states should be below this threshold.

When I made my first prediction back in December, there were only 8, and at this time I count 11 states. I think we are still seeing the effect of holiday gatherings and that the number will go down slightly going in to early spring as more people get vaccinated. However, I still think it will be more than I had initially guessed.

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC dropped to 0.97 in the report this morning at Rt.live.  11 states currently meet the 75.0 or higher criteria.  As others have observed, the Rt data has bounced all over the place, so I should not base my bet completely on the Rt numbers not bouncing up yet again.  But for now I choose to follow the data.

Today 11.
The number of daily and weekly cases has been decreasing since January 11th (source: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/united-states?country=~USA)
It is unlikely that there will be a new wave given the current restrictions and the vaccine

Was pretty aggressive on the lower end and with less than a month and a half left there are 11 states above 75. I'm still feeling like the lower end is more likely but also feeling like I was too aggressive at first and another wave is always possible. So evenly distributing for now, will check back in a week or so and see where things stand.

11 above 75, 36 with 1.0 infection rate or more
Dropped 12 in 5 days
My cautious brain says I should keep some beans on the top bracket -- open ended ranges can be attractive.  But I'm going to go with the trend, which is down.
The average Rt for the 50 states + DC dropped to 0.987 over the past two days.  At least for now the curves are trending down.  Based on https://rt.live I'll move towards lower brackets.
Currently at 14 states, and very little sign of decrease across the nation. Going to be paying attention through feb.

Currently 16 states >75 Potential for new strain(s) to further accelerate growth or shift to new areas. Biden could implement strict controls from Jan 21, but they may take >1 month to have full effect, especially given current rates of infection

Today we dropped from 20 states >=75.0 to 16.  And the average Rt for the 50 states+DC dropped to just above 1.00.  We seem to be moving down.  First I favored the lower brackets, only yesterday switched to the higher ranges, and now I'll overweight the middle ranges.  That's my final answer, ... for now.  :-) This forecast could blow up if the B.1.1.7 mutation increases in prevalence over the next 6 weeks.  See https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/coronavirus-variant-dominant-us/2021/01/15/4420d814-5738-11eb-a817-e5e7f8a406d6_story.html

After looking at the graphs for each of the states I believe my previous forecasts were wildly optimistic.  I'll move towards the higher bins.  If the graphs turn downward I'll revisit.  A more transmissive new strain is also an X-factor.  Vaccinations, IMHO, won't have a noticeable effect until April or May.  If the end date were April 1 I would be more optimistic.

today: >10
Contrary to my last prediction, none of the factors mentioned seem to diminish the intensity of the epidemic.
There is no reason to think that things will improve significantly in the coming weeks.
In addition, I tend to be overly optimistic in my previous forecast about COVID, compared to reality and other forecasters.

Currently at 22 states with greater than 75 cases per 100k. Past peaks have risen quickly and taken a long time to taper off. Vaccination is a new factor that changes how this wave will taper off, however I am bearish on the rate of vaccination in the USA, and I expect that the presence of a vaccine may lead to further disregard of mask wearing orders suggesting that 10 or more states are very likely to be above this threshold.
I am expecting the daily case count to start falling by end of this week. But now I am not sure if we can go down from 22 states to 3 states by March 1st. So moving some weightage to bin3
Decreasing forecast again due to the growing possibility that herd immunity could start to reduce infection rates *despite* the new variant (YYG predicts 40% of US will be immune by this date)
Adjusting based on spread of new variant (B117)
I'm increasing the probabilities at higher numbers of states. The newer variant seems to have been introduced and a large number of states now have >75.0

Today there are 12 states above 75/100k. However, it's unlikely that these 12 states will still be over 75/100k in 2 months. Even states like the Dakotas did not sustain 2mo of over 75/100k. However, the new variant is more infectious, and it's possible some of these states below 75/100k are going to rise. Also, it's unlikely the vaccine distribution will make a meaningful dent here by March 1, since only ~5% of the US pop will be vaccinated by then. I think it's a low chance of 0, and a meaningful chance of the other three choices.

Most states have at one time or another surpassed the 75 per 100k new case rate.  The states that have substantially exceeded that rate have so far seen their new infection rates fall and not reach such a high level a second time.  It's a pretty high bar, so I'm favoring the lower ranges.
Redistributing a bit to be less confident on the lower end.

12 states now, many others increasing
expect to peak in about 10 days,
 Biden from jan 20th. 
ny, az 1st peak halved in 1 mo
Very hard to predict, most uncertain on upside

Not a massive change to my previous forecast, but a small weighting higher. The discovery of the new UK variant in New York is not that surprising. What has influenced my decision is that the case does not belong to someone who has had direct contact with someone who has travelled to/from the UK. Govenor Cuomo suggested that the strain may be much more widespread than believed.

The 7 day rolling average [1] is now following the exact same pattern as it did around Thanksgiving. I am expecting the new cases to plateau around Jan 15th and maybe start falling by Jan 20th-25th.
Right now, I will stick with heavy on bin 1 & 2 but I will come back and relook evaluate around Jan 15th. [1] https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
Cases are not growing at a relevant rate.

There are currently 8 states with a rate of at least 75 per 100k residents.  There are 13 total states with rates over 70.  As the cold weather continues and social distancing remains difficult, it seems likely that the number of cases will continue to grow over the next two months.  The only thing reducing this could be vaccines, but the US has only administered 4.33 million doses of the first of two shots at this point (1.3% of the population).  While the vaccine distribution pace is due to increase, it will likely only have a negligable effect on new cases by March 1 at the current rate.

Right now there are 6 states (though the cdc website is showing 8 -  https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#cases_casesper100klast7days - I’ll have to dig deeper into the discrepancy).  When looking at past outbreaks and the summer outbreak, not many of the worse-hit states (like Florida and Texas) saw spikes above 75/100k. The same is true for places like New York during the first outbreak. This could be due to less available testing, but it lowers the base rate for the >6 buckets.  Further vaccine roll-out could also stunt these numbers. While I’m only cautiously optimistic given recent rollout target misses, I think it will only get better. Holiday travel was also higher than most health authorities wanted, but cases per 100k did not seem to cross the 75 threshold in most states. With the holiday season largely over, I don’t think it is unreasonable to expect cases to plateau or fall as less travel ensues.  One thing I want to explore is how lagged infection rate (R^0) impacts future cases per 100k. I also am going to be watching vaccine rollouts relative to projections.
Decided I was probably being overconfident on zero so coming down a little.

Hard to extrapolate. A lot depends on the ability of the US to keep the newer strain out, and how soon it takes serious steps. I also don't want to discount any potential effects of the inaugration. Would love to know if flu rates are known to increase just after previous inaugrations.
However the US seems to like having the UK as a friend. Shutting borders is not a good look on that basis. Therefore I have been fairly conservative with my probabilities at low numbers.
Currently 4 states meet criteria. Vaccination will start slowing spread during February.
Significant risk of infection-rate acceleration from new B117 variant with much higher R0, although might be more than two months to percolate through

I am trending downward in this. I understand the implications of the mutation on overall infection rate. But we are lighting a backfire with the CoVid Vaccine. Throw in Biden’s focus on both accelerating the vaccinations and calling for people to act with sanity, and I see the numbers falling in March.  We have a force causing a rise, and a force lowering the numbers.   Most locations will crest by the end of January, so even without a vaccine, I really cannot see these numbers happening in March, with no major holidays in between.  Currently only four states are in this category. Looking at the 2018 Flu stats, by March in a normal year, numbers are dropping significantly. While not directly linked to CoVid, it is the closest info we have. https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/pastreports.htm
Shifting my thinking on this one, ... again.  The pandemic is currently very serious, and yet only 4 states exceed the "75.0 or higher" threshold.  I'll overweight the lower two ranges.

With only two months to go, the vaccine will probably not yet have the virus under control by March 1.  Some states are lagging on vaccine administration.  WV has vaccinated the most people, 2.5% of the population; KS has reached the fewest, 0.42%.  See https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/?sref=x7nYEkiY So I'll underweight (slightly) the "Zero" outcome, thinking there could still be a few outliers in late February.

Copying @Mark-Hadman rationale (but with a different conclusion): Currently only 4 states appear to be above this threshold (CA, TN, RI, AZ according to https://ig.ft.com/coronavirus-chart ), and most states appear to be declining or holding level. The current reports of overwhelmed hospitals (which will only get worse in the wake of Christmas/NY) combined with a new federal administration and accelerating vaccine rollout will combine to mean that a likely early-2021 spike will be on a downward trajectory well before 1 March.

Currently only 4 states appear to be above this threshold (CA, TN, RI, AZ according to https://ig.ft.com/coronavirus-chart ), and most states appear to be declining or holding level.  The current reports of overwhelmed hospitals (which will only get worse in the wake of Christmas/NY) combined with a new federal administration and accelerating vaccine rollout will combine to mean that a likely early-2021 spike will be on a downward trajectory well before 1 March.

Based on forecasts, many states are likely to continue to have daily infections of more than 75 per 100,000. Many states currently (as of Dec 29th, 2021) have well over 200 cases per 100k. News is also coming out of a slower rollout of vaccines across the US than was advertised. This doesn’t give me confidence that enough people by may will have been vaccinated that would lower the incidents of daily infections.  My prediction is that 20 or more states are likely to be at or above 75 daily cases per 100K as of March 1st, 2021.

Rate of new cases between different states tend to mirror each other, meaning the most likely scenarios are either zero states above 75, or 10+ states above 75 in the event of a large 3rd wave. I increased the odds of 1-3 states for two reasons: (1) this would account for a few potential outliers, and (2) there are currently 3 states above 75 and the best prediction is often what is currently happening.

On Dec 29 2020 four states had more than 75 new cases per 100K inhabitants. Infection rate shows controlled and slowing down virus spread, so there is a possibility that the number of states having 0.75 result will not increase. As two months left and most of states have decreasing infection trends, it's likely to be 1-3 states with the result  in question.

Seems unlikely a "third wave" could get sufficient momentum by then, but within the realm of possibility. On average I expect things will be better. If the new strain turns out to be much more transmissible, that could result in a faster resurgence.

On Dec 27 2020 only four states had more than 75 new cases per 100K inhabitants.  All states except 8 had a downward trend for new daily cases during weeks 51 and 52. My base estimate is that the second wave is already over, and that statewide counts will continue to go down. But I hedge with low probabilities for up to 6 states. One uncertainty should be noted. The daily counts are very variable, and any single day can be loaded with a backlog of reporting. For example the average for Texas from 11/30 to 12/27 was 16000 with a standard deviation of 10187, the reason being a single day with 50000 new reported cases. If March 1st happens to be a day with such single day "loading" for several states, everybody's estimates will be derailed.

The site in the question lists 4. Harvard lists 9 (https://globalepidemics.org/key-metrics-for-covid-suppression/). Either way, it's about 13 weeks away, and a lot can happen to drive these numbers down. They could also go back up, as people think that herd immunity is an immediate effect of the vaccine. Still, I think it'll trend downward by the end of March.
Peak already reached by 2021-01-01 in all states

1. The test positivity rate is >7 in over 30 states. That means that they do not have a clear understanding of what is happening.
2. Some other statistics: a. the number of infected individuals is possibly 9 or greater than the test positivity rate see Pullano et al. Nature https://doi.org/fn9k; 2020). the The states are continuing to hire contact tracing staff  and will continue to identify all these patients including the 40% that are asymptomatic

Currently 4. This is likely to follow the flu season curve. Since the flu is only showing about one third the cases that it has in any time in history, it seems clear that a large number of the reported covid cases are actually flu cases, especially when you consider that the WHO, the CDC, and the New York times have all stated that the PCR testing has a high chance of false positives. Florida is now requiring its testing centers to report the viral load limits and number of cycles that they use which should result in a lower number of positive cases from that state. It is possible that other states will follow Florida's example.  I don't think that it's a coincidence that the authorities are now officially recognizing the problems with the PCR testing right at the same time that Biden is taking over and at the same time the vaccine is being brought out. If they start looking at the number of cycles used and start using these PCR tests in a more accurate way it will mean many fewer reported cases which could then be attributed to the vaccine. For reference
TN 108.2
CA 102.2
AZ 83.4
RI 79.0

25 states seem to have the virus under control. 25 states are already above 50 cases per 100k . I dont really see any reason at this time that they will get lower . The vaccines wont have covered enough people to affect the virus velocity of spread by March.  Biden might make a difference but not sure. I think the existing states above 50 all will continue to rise and inevitably they will peak 75.

It’s out of control, the new variants are coming and the vaccine won’t be sufficiently distributed by that point, even if it works.....oh, and about 45% of voters seem to think taking COVID precautions means you are somehow disloyal to Trump or the Republicans

Inference based solely on the evolution of the curves for each state; evolution observed here: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#compare-trends_newcasesper100k
I didn't put 100% on zero just on principle.

I think they are already close to this percentage and the situation with the new strain and slowness in rolling out the vaccines won't make the situation better. There were 50 M people older  than 62 in 2010( probably near 60M now). 50 M x 2 shuts / 52 weeks in a year = 3.8 million shuts per week to be done in a year. However we would need 7.7 M if target is to finish by mid year. At the moment the US is putting around 1.4  M per week and the UK only 350k per week.  Even if speed improves, that it will, I do not think vaccination would be a game changer by March and I doubt it would be by mid year.
The vaccine rollout will continue to be slow and average citizen compliance will be unchanged.
Even with a vaccine, it remains unknown if the vaccine reduces the number of infections or just the number of serious cases.

For most of the pandemic, no states were >=75 daily new cases per 100k. This would suggest putting most of the probability on zero or 1--3 states having >= 75 daily new cases. However, there will be more testing on March 1st than during most of the pandemic. Also, as of December 26th, it is likely that more people are actually sick (whether tested or not) than during earlier stages of the pandemic, and this will likely not have completely changed in two months. Visual inspection of the graphs of active cases suggest that the descent after a maximum is much slower than the ascent to the maximum. Hence, it is likely that there are more cases and more positive test cases on March 1st than during most of the pandemic. More contagious strains could further increase the number of cases. Thus, we adjust the estimate to putting most of the probability mass on 4--6 (50%) and still a considerable probability on 7--9 (35%). There are a few factors that will exercise a downward pressure on new cases: more people will have had the virus already. Some people will be vaccinated by mid-February. Officials estimate that there will be doses for about 100 million people being available by the end of February.[1] Not all of those doses will be administered by then, so I estimate about 60 million people (~1/5th of the population) to be vaccinated by the end of February. I naively assume that this will reduce cases by about 1/5th relative what they would have been without vaccines. This means we shift some fraction of the probability we currently put on 7 and 9 down to 4 and 6, and so on. [1] https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-covid-19-vaccine-when-will-it-be-available-for-you-11606339361

Ce jour 8 états sur 53 * Nb de cas réel en mars :
Arg + :
- Arg - :
- pas rassemblements festifs massifs (noel, nouvel an, vacances)+++++
- gens seront plus en extérieur car journées plus longues++
- vaccin
- Trump plus au pouvoir donc populations mieux informée rationnellement Arg pareil = hiver Pratiques des tests en mars : moins du fait du vaccin + habitus des gens
Preliminary forecast based on it being unlikely in my opinion that March is anywhere close to as bad as this peak. Vaccine will play a small role by then as well.

Question is whether Biden inspired mask/lockdown mandates from Jan 21 make enough difference in 5 weeks. High positivity rates in some states suggest under-testing at the moment Significant risk from new strains accelerating spread

Currently 9 even with post Thanksgiving surge. In Missouri surge went down after three weeks, although still not safe. Schools returning after Christmas and new variations are all factors.  Vaccine will be too new to have a significant effect.  Will adjust as time goes on and these questions are resolved.
Initial forecast -- overweighting bottom three buckets
Even with a vaccine, people will continue to be dangerously stupid.
